bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 26, 1942

div1.p: Kean informs Hench that he has discussed Lazear's lab book with Truby and notes areas where they differed and their final agreements. Kean and Truby agree that Ames' alleged case of yellow fever was an error in diagnosis.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, June 26, 1942

opener.dateline:
2804 N STREET. N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C.
June 26, 1942

div1.p:
I fear you think I am a great
daudler not to have sent you
your photostat MSS before this
and you would be entirely right-
I waste time terribly, when so little
of it is, in all probilily, left for me
to waste and on matters that are
relatively unimportant- But yes-
terday I got together all your
MSS and have wrapped them
up carefully and they are now
waiting for the Express man to
come and get them. I feel a little
ashamed at following your injunc-
tion that they be sent collect but
2
as my bank balance is now down
to a bare $500 and it is still some
days to the end of the month. I
must count the pennies not to get
into the red. Gen. Truby and I
have been over all the sheets and
after each had read the copy of
Lazear's laboratory book, we went
over the remarks we had written on
the backs together and discussed
the few minor points in which
we had differed & noted our
final agreements. I was especi-
ally interested in the record of Dr
R. P. Ames alleged case of yellow fever
and we entirely agreed that this
was certainly an error of diagnosis-
It may have been some digestive
3
upset as he was a very heavy
eater- Truby remarked “Of course
you know he had syphilis- I said
yes I had heard so. Well said
Truby, there is no doubt of it, as
he talked of it openly among us
doctors, and I have heard him
say so myself.” This explains why
he always sought jobs away from
home, and did not live with his
quite good looking wife- He did
a good job however in the Marianao
epidemic and I, for one, should
be grateful for his good care of
me, in my attack. And I am, altho.
when I recall the senseless experiment
on the young private Driscoll at Fort
McIntosh Texas in Nov. 1903, when
4
he put Driscoll's life in jeopardy
and undermined his health so that
he had to be discharged for disa-
bility- When I think of that, as Horace
puts it, surgit aliquid amari - which
leaves a bitter taste in my mouth-

x x x Right here General Truby came
in to tell me how he had got his
son Jack the West Point Cadetship-
He is very happy over it and will
go up to New York with him on
Tuesday the 30th I have a young
grandson staying with me, who
will go up at the same time-
Truby sends his regards and as
he went out of the door just now said
“Be sure to tell Dr. Hench about Jack”
div1.closer:
J. R. Kean Let me know when is the date when you go into the
service-
